awd_titl_txt: EAGER/RUI:   One-Step, Programed Alignment of Liquid Crystal Elastomers by Guest Host Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will demonstrate feasibility for a novel one-step printing and polymerization process for liquid crystal material. Liquid crystals are rod-like, rigid molecules that have both liquid-like (free diffusion of molecules) and solid-like properties (ordered molecular arrangements). Liquid crystal elastomers are rubbery materials made from liquid crystal repeat units connected together in long chains forming a true solid. It has been observed that when all the liquid crystal units line up in the same direction that material size changes of 300-400 percent can be produced by heating. These large, reversible deformations could be extremely useful for a variety of applications such as soft, synthetic muscle actuators or rewriteable braille displays. Unfortunately, alignment is difficult to attain while forming the material into the complex structural shapes typically required for practical devices. This award supports fundamental research to demonstrate the feasibility of a new process for aligning these materials during manufacture. This new process will enable advancement toward 3D printing of aligned elastomer materials which will empower new applications in the biomedical, aerospace, chemical, and energy industries. As a result, this work will enhance the U.S. economy, society, and global competitiveness. Additionally, this research will directly benefit the STEM workforce by enhancing engineering education and persistence to graduation among undergraduate participants at a primarily undergraduate institution.

Current approaches to fabricating responsive liquid crystal elastomers rely on elaborate procedures to align the liquid crystal units that represent a serious impediment to the widespread development of these materials for practical applications. The objective of this research is to generate a one-step, facile technique for orienting liquid crystal moieties in the material bulk while simultaneously fixing the alignment through network cross-linking. The alignment will be obtained using guest host interactions between the liquid crystals and photo-responsive dopants.  To produce robust alignment of the liquid crystal elastomer the various reaction processes must proceed simultaneously, but with distinct time scales. The approach for this work will involve a systematic exploration of the combined reaction kinetics in order to clarify their role in liquid crystal alignment. Kinetics will be characterized by in situ infrared spectroscopy. Aligned elastomers will be characterized by several techniques including, polarized ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, differential scanning calorimetry, and dynamic mechanical analysis. The contribution of this research to the greater body of knowledge will be significant because it will advance understanding of how material anisotropies can be controlled in situ during manufacturing processes such as 3D printing, enabling the design of adaptive, shape-programmable structures and devices by a broad range of engineers and applied scientists.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this award was to generate fundamental knowledge with regard to one-step photo-alignment techniques for liquid crystal elastomers in which polymer network formation and liquid crystal alignment occur simultaneously. Liquid crystals are rod-like, rigid molecules that have both liquid-like (free diffusion of molecules) and solid-like properties (ordered molecular arrangements). Liquid crystal elastomers are rubbery materials made from liquid crystal repeat units connected together in long chains forming a true solid. It has been observed that when all the liquid crystal units line up in the same direction (aligned), that material size changes of 300-400% can be produced by heating. These large, reversible deformations could be extremely useful for a variety of applications such as soft, synthetic muscle actuators or rewriteable braille displays. 

The one-step alignment approach examined in this work involved using guest host interactions between the liquid crystal constituents and rod-like photo-responsive dopants, which are aligned with polarized ultraviolet light. To produce robust alignment of liquid crystal elastomers, various reaction processes must proceed simultaneously, but with distinct time scales. The primary tool used examine these time scales was heated, real time infrared spectroscopy in which the consumption of various reactants can be observed in real time at an assortment of reaction temperatures. A variety of reaction conditions that could be amenable to one-step alignment of LCEs including a suitable reaction catalyst, reactant concentrations, and thermal processing temperatures were identified. However, unwanted side reactions induced by the uv light proved to be a challenging obstacle.  Potential pathways and reactants that mitigate unwanted side reactions to a degree, but not completely, were determined. As a result, feasibility of the one-step approach remains questionable. 

While the one-step alignment process has yet to be fully demonstrated, knowledge of favorable conditions has been generated and may enable the approach to be successfully investigated further. A parallel approach involving the synthesis of liquid crystal polymer chains with photo-alignable side groups was also pursued. These polymers were investigated because they decouple the alignment and polymerization steps, thus circumventing uv induced side reactions during polymerization. Polymer chains with the photo-alignable side groups were synthesized and basic proof of concept experiments performed under uv light were successful. Investigation of the one-step and decoupled approaches both supplied knowledge necessary to pursue a facile technique for aligning liquid crystal elastomers. This knowledge is expected to help facilitate the development of methods for the fabrication of complex 2D and 3D responsive LCE structures for applications such as energy dissipation, morphing structures, and soft robotics which are important in the biomedical, aerospace, chemical, and energy industries.

This research also directly benefited the STEM workforce by enhancing engineering education and persistence to graduation among undergraduate research participants at a primarily undergraduate institution. It is well known that early research or research-like experiences increase understanding, confidence, and motivation in students, which leads to greater persistence. Two undergraduate research students began participation in this project during or before their fourth semester of college. One student was from an underrepresented group in STEM. Each received intensive research training and mentoring. Their work resulted in both students giving presentations at national conferences. Both are persisting toward graduation in engineering, with the underrepresented student planning to pursue a doctoral degree (they had not seriously considered graduate school prior to their research experience). Within the PIs research group, 4 additional students (2 underrepresented) were impacted indirectly by this award. They learned characterization and synthesis techniques that were generated from this project, performed sample tests, and were involved in group meetings and problem solving discussions and other efforts such as small molecule synthesis and fabrication of nanoparticle infused materials that spun off of the findings from this project. In addition, this project supported a research based organic chemistry lab course by proposing compelling target molecules to be synthesized.  Three chemical engineering or chemistry students who worked on the molecules were directly impacted and approximately 40 sophomore level chemistry students in the course were indirectly impacted by being exposed to information and challenges regarding this project. Concepts and techniques from this project were also incorporated into a first-year engineering materials course, which will impact approximately 70 engineering students annually. By facilitating early research experiences and introducing cutting edge topics in first and second year courses in engineering and chemistry, this project is already significantly impacting the preparation of students and their persistence intounderr STEM careers, and thus supporting the development of a competitive STEM workforce.
